entry.title: Reflection, final half
entry.content:
The story arc of my diploma may not be obvious to someone reading my designs, but for me, I can really see how I'm learning. It's been very challenging, because I thought I'd be learning about how to make maps, how to use ...  and I have learnt a lot of that, but what I've learnt most is that it's the people stuff that matters most. I've seen it done badly. Really badly. And I don't want to replicate that. 

Resilience. 

I used the forum to share my Community Gardens People design, but I didn't hace time to heed their advice. I then duly forgot about it, as I hadn't done the reflection - probably due to aversion to looking at the project any more, and then got drawn into the whole Hellbent story, where all those things would have served me very nicely. I got back into my pattern!  

I realised during the CG design that I wanted to work collaboratively on future designs, and I have done so on another design.

Having a body of work to look back on means that I can see very clearly the learning, the patterns, the areas I need to work on in myself, to come to terms with aspects of my character and also, where to set boundaries, and how to make decisions about projects I want to get involved with in the future. I am learning so much about myself.

entry.title: 100 Days of Permaculture
entry.content:
Day four, 24/05/22

It’s day 4 of #100daysofpermaculture and I spent nearly all of it in my new office, finishing off a couple of designs that were from tricky situations. So it’s been quite challenging as I’ve just wanted to do some more organising, do some more ‘research’ or ‘networking ‘ on Facebook/Instagram. Despite this, I’ve made good progress and have crossed lots of tasks off my to do list. But I still haven’t called my mum, so I’m going to stop work once I’ve posted this.
1.The view from my office window (if I crank my head out and to the left). Oh, how I love Cow Parsley!!
2. The actual view is of the yard where there’s lots of resources waiting for their next project. Still not too shabby a view, and the birdsong is incredible.
 
#permaculture #permaculturedesign #permaculturestudentsofinstagram #diplomainappliedpermaculturedesign #cowparsley #100daychallenge
 
 
 

And now we’re off out for dinner to celebrate!

Day Two 22/05/22

This is a screenshot of a slide from a design I’m writing up for my diploma. My sixth design. It’s a quote from @loobymacnamara of @applewood_permaculture_centre
The design is about boundaries and the circle of concern tool was of great use, and I think it’s a great tool for daily life. Looby puts it really well 😊

Day One 21/05/22

Today was day one of 100 days of Permaculture!!!
I’ve been working on my Diploma in Applied Permaculture since 2019, and I’m halfway through. I’ve got to raise my game as I’ve just been given the go ahead to do my accreditation event at this year’s National Permaculture Gathering. Yoiks! So, to keep up the momentum, I’m going to do a 100 day challenge. I’ll be posting every day, until the event. There’s more than 100 days but I’m off on retreat, but I can still fit in 100).
Luckily, I’m at a lovely farm @Brookside.eco.farm where Permaculture is very much embraced, and it looks as though we might be staying! I’ll be doing at least one design for them, there’s lots of exciting stuff happening!
These pictures are of the incredible WET system they had installed. It cleans all the grey and brown water from the main buildings, as it passes through five ponds. The water is cleaned by diverse range of trees and perennials, many of which provide food or other uses. By the fifth pond, it’s clean enough to swim in!
Not only that, walking through it is heavenly.
Also, Benji has become a reluctant member of a pack of four dogs, this is Trewa. It was quite a challenge to get a shot of them together.
Today I finished the amendments for my first five designs. I’m taking on a big challenge, but I’m going to give it everything I’ve got. I hope you’ll enjoy following my progress-wish me luck!!
#permaculturediplomastudentsofinstagram
#permaculture #permaculturediploma #bethechange #100daysofpermaculture #100daychallenge

entry.content:

  • Survey

Overview 

Aim

This design will look at different composting systems and how they could fit into the site to create an effective composting process.

Date

November - December 2020

Location

 Wibsey Community Gardens, Wibsey, Bradford, West Yorkshire, U.K.

Client

 Wibsey Community Gardens, Wibsey, Bradford, West Yorkshire, U.K.

Status

Not implemented
Submitted for intermediate portfolio assessment, assessment pending

Area of Application

 Land

Principles

 Holmgren and Mollison

Framework

SADIMET

Survey, Analysis, Decisions, Implementation, Maintenance, Evaluation, Tweak

Tools

PASTE, zoning, Plus and minus, flowchart, elements matrix, hierarchy of resource use diagram, SMART goals, Spirals of erosion/abundance, 

Resources/support

Miro, GanttProject, YouTube, Permaculture Design by Aranya, The Earth Path by Starhawk

Context

Wibsey Community Gardens is on a 2.5 acre site that was previously the Bradford Council Parks Dept shrub nursery. It was leased to Bradford Community Environment Project (BCEP) until they folded and the site was taken on by Bradford Organic Community Services in 2017. I was employed BOCS in 2020 as community gardener. The site has three commercial polytunnels and also a large number of raised beds in the open ground. The key objective of my role was to grow produce.

I saw the need and possibility of producing compost, to support the fruit and vegetable production.
A lot of organic materials are available for use on the site. It would be possible to recycle them and turn them into high quality compost to support the growth of healthy plants. There is potential to create different types of compost for different purposes.
The current composting system is not working. It has been neglected and doesn't function effectively. There are many opportunities for composting waste that are being missed.
Loam wasn't built in a day

- unknown

Survey

What are the priorities?

  • To create high quality compost to support food production

What are the additional things it would be nice to have?

  • to train staff and volunteers how to use the compost systems
  • To run composting workshops for staff, volunteers and visitors
  • Food waste collection/donation from local community

What is the vision for the site?

  • To be community-sufficient in compost
  • To have efficient, low maintenance systems 
  • To have a straightforward system that processes all waste from the veg production areas
  • For the systems to be close to where waste is produced

There is a small budget available for the overall growing project and some of it can be used for the composting systems. Investments made in composting systems will result in savings in the future as it will reduce or even prevent the need to buy in compost.

Timescale - It would be beneficial to start developing the compost systems straightaway, so as to reduce the need for buying in compost next year.

The different composts will take between six months and two years to cure. 

Why is compost needed?

There are 144 raised beds on the site. A wide variety of food crops are grown in these, to be sold to visitors, cafes and shops. The growing media in the beds is depleted as crops have been harvested but they have not been adequately topped up with compost, if at all. The beds need topping up as a matter of urgency. In the first year, it will be necessary to top up with bought-in compost but this is expensive and results in increased carbon emissions. 

Healthy soil means healthy crops that are more resilient to pests and drought. Healthy soil also yields crops with higher nutritional content. 

Why a redesign?

The current system is not effective because;

  • The current bays are too far from most of the working areas
  • Workers don't know what to put where so they dump everything on The Heap
  • The compost bays are not safe as the paths are slippery and there is run-off pooling on the paths 
  • Grass clippings from the bowling green in the park are being used. It is likely that these contain chemical treatments such as pesticides and herbicides
  • The current bays are wooden and are rotting
  • There are bits of timber lying around, some with nails in
  • The Heap is now home to nesting birds, foxes and possibly hedgehogs and more
  • There is very little compost being made on site, and a lot is needed
  • The volunteer who was maintaining the compost bays could not continue due to the pandemic
  • Workers have little knowledge about composting

What is working well?

  • There are some good paths in place

The Site

I used Miro software for parts of the survey. It is tricky to navigate so I have created a video to talk through the process. 

This link will allow you to look at the Miro board in your own time.

Site Location

Details of this can be found here

Climate and landform

In choosing what to survey, I thought about the design and it's requirements. I wanted to make sure I was only surveying that which was pertinent to the design. For example, there was no point in doing soil tests because nearly all of the growing at this stage is done in raised beds.

Climate does affect composting to a point, but in the climate of West Yorkshire, the effects are negligible.

Rainfall is significant throughout the year.

Prevailing winds are from the west. As the site is on a hill, it is a windy site and the average windspeed is 19 km/h. Gusting speeds can be as high as 90km/h (worldwideweatheronline.com)

Site info

P.A.S.T.E.

People

Who will be involved in the composting systems and how?

Who What
Staff Building compost systems, adding to compost bays, maintenance of compost bays, using compost, training, eating crops grown in compost
Volunteers Adding to compost bays, using compost, being trained, eating crops grown in compost
Visitors Attending compost workshops, enjoying seeing crops growing in compost, eating crops grown in compost
Customers Eating crops grown in compost

Zoning

I did a very rough zoning exercise, to think about how the site is used.

Zone 1 is where most activity takes place.

Zone 2 is where quite a lot of activity takes place

Zone 3 is visited sometimes

Zone 4 is is rarely visited

Sector analysis

I decided that sector analysis wasn't necessary for this design, it was enough to know which way the prevailing winds came from so that strong winds do not damage any systems put in place.

Flood zones were considered as building a compost system in an area that floods could cause run off pollution and nutrient loss as well as slowing down the composting process.

Frost is not usually an issue when making and using compost as it isn't generally used in winter and systems are adequately covered to protect against the elements.

Drought will not be significant enough to affect the composting systems and use thereof.

Sun mapping is not required.

Water systems

I have included these in the survey video as some composting systems may require irrigation.

Soil

The majority of the crops are grown in raised beds, so soil testing would not have been appropriate. There are a large number of beds and they have been topped up with various substrates at different times, so each bed would have had to have been tested, which would not be a sensible use of resources.

Site utilities

The site has running water and electricity. Polytunnel 3 has an electricity point.

Free or cheap resources

Organic waste from the site

  • pernicious weeds
  • other weeds
  • willow branches
  • hazel branches
  • food waste from volunteers and workers

The site is within a highly urbanised area, so there are many opportunities for sourcing cheap and free materials such as;

  • woodchip from local arborist
  • leaves collected by local council
  • food waste from box scheme when it is up and running 
  • IBCs can be purchased cheaply
  • Manure from staff's family
  • Pallets
  • Cardboard
  • Old fencing that could be re-purposed

One key resource is land - there is plenty of space to install any number of composting systems 

The urban location also means that it is relatively easy to take deliveries of other materials, such as building materials.

Analysis

Your challenge is to integrate [the client's] needs with the needs of the environment and still give them everything they ask for.

- Aranya

Limiting Factors - Site

  • Large amount of organic matter not being composted effectively
  • Current composting systems are too far from most activity
  • Flooding

Limiting factors  - non-physical

  • Woodchip from local arborist not being used (apart from for paths)
  • Local council can provide leaves in autumn but connections are not there
  • Workers are not learning about composting
  • There are not enough workers
  • There may be limits of what level of composting can be undertaken - research
  • Staff may not have time to maintain systems and train volunteers and other staff
  • Management, workers and volunteers don't understand why it's important to make compost

Functions, systems and elements

 

The key functions of the composting system are; 

  • Maintaining a closed loop
  • Nutrient cycling
  • Supporting plant growth
  • Increasing biodiversity
  • Soil carbon sequestration
  • Low maintenance
  • Water saving 
  • Weed reduction

I considered which elements performed which functions

 

I thought about how the inputs and outputs were processed.

Hierarchy of Resource Use

I used this tool to indicate which resources are good to use and which are to be avoided. It serves as an excellent reminder that making compost on site removes the import of peat (often a component in commercial compost mixes). #EarthCare

As willow and hazel increase with modest use, it makes a lot of sense to use them for ramial woodchip. 

Goals

Needs

  • make enough compost to meet needs on site to be community sufficient
  • close the loop of organic material being wasted/processed inefficiently
  • create low maintenance systems
  • make sure that weeds are composted effectively so that weed seed and roots are killed in the process
  • design durable systems - sustainability is met through implementation of ethics
  • place systems where they are needed

Aims for the future/separate designs

  • ensure workers are safe  - this is part of the clean-up project
  • provide workers with clear guidance on how to use systems - this is part of communication and training project
  • ensure future gardeners understand the system - this is part of communication and training project

I then converted these into SMART goals, shown below. Each goal is numbered and on a coloured sticky note so you can follow the progression of each goal through the five questions.

I thought about the goals and created mini mind maps of each one. I'm not sure why, or what they do...

I did plus and minus analysis of a variety of systems

Then I looked more in-depth at the systems that seemed like the best fit

Decisions

The key decisions were about what systems to use and where to put them. 

I decided to use a wide variety of systems so that all of the materials on offer could be utilised.  As there was no shortage of space, there was room for a good number of systems.

I made a video in which I explain my design decisions;

Implementation

The implementation plan including; a project plan in the form of a Gantt chart, a breakdown of costings, chipper research and implementation of each system can be seen here

Maintenance

To a certain extent, using the systems is a major part of their maintenance. As one function for the systems was 'low maintenance', as a whole the system should be fairly low maintenance.

I wrote a basic maintenance plan. It is only basic because I did not stay in that job. 

Had I stayed, I would have done a design around communication for how to use the systems. This would have allowed more people to be involved in the maintenance.

Evaluation

In-depth evaluation was not possible for this design as it wasn't implemented. But as far as I can tell, if the design had been implemented, the SMART goals would have been achieved. 

 

 

Tweak

Looking back at this design I can imagine that it would have been necessary to build a composting system in the old raised beds area. I chose not to put one there as I wasn't sure how much capacity we needed for the outdoor raised beds waste and I wanted to make sure that the one-turn system had enough material. 

I would hope that we would have found a way to produce ramial wood chip. As the forest garden project was a long way from being implemented and using rwc in vegetable beds can be tricky, it was maybe for the best. 

I suspect that some systems would have performed better and that those may have replaced ones that didn't do as well. But having incorporated a divers range of systems means that the best fit would have become evident over time.

Availability of inputs may have changed such as if the tree surgeons stopped providing free wood chip or we may have set up a community composting system. Developing systems for these changes would have been necessary

Principles

In addition to those mentioned in the design decisions video, below are the ways that the principles come into use 

Catch and Store Energy: By developing systems that collect resources when they are abundant, we can use them in times of need.

In closing the nutrient loop by gathering organic materials and recycling them into compost, what would have been lost has been put to best use. 

Obtain a Yield: Ensure that you are getting truly useful rewards as part of the work that you are doing.

This is a key principle for this design. The main yield is compost, and it a invaluable resource for the broader project. The efficiencies integrated into this design will mean that the yield is increased at little cost and with myriad benefits.

Use & value renewable resources & services: Make the best use of nature’s abundance to reduce our consumptive behaviour and dependence on non-renewable resources.

Another key principle, the design is energy and resource efficient, using resources that are on site or free. By making our own compost, we are closing the loop, and reducing use of peat, synthetic fertilisers, perlite, plastics and fossil fuels.

Using salvaged materials where possible to build the compost systems reduces the need for purchasing new materials that have a carbon footprint.

Using willow and hazel for ramial wood chip  means that a resource that is truly renewable is being put to good use, and as using it actually increases the resource and reduces growth that is problematic, the benefits are numerous.

Produce no waste: By valuing and making use of all the resources that are available to us, nothing goes to waste.

By valuing all plant material, including so-called pernicious weeds, nutrients and organic matter are cycled and a yield results. By using coppiced willow (some of which are unwanted), hazel and other trees, something that is otherwise problematic is put to excellent use. In using woodchip in efficient systems, the mycorrhizal process produces highly nutritious compost. 

Integrate rather than segregate: By putting the right things in the right place, relationships develop between them and they support each other.

Choosing the right place for each compost system, in relation to it's use and functions means that they can function all the better and will not be problematic. Placing systems in the correct zones means that they are more likely to be maintained and used effectively.

Use and value diversity: Diversity reduces vulnerability to a variety of threats and takes advantage of the unique nature of the environment in which it resides.

By using a variety of systems, we will produce a variety of composts, with different properties for different uses. We will be supporting a diverse flora and fauna, which in turn will support the wider environment, such as the parks and gardens beyond the site.

Ethics

Earth Care
Earth Care is very much at the forefront of this design. The soil of this ex-council nursery has been depleted but can be regenerated through the introduction of large amounts of compost, and the resulting increased biodiversity. The following practices are also in line with Earth Care;

  • reducing use of bought in compost 
  • not using peat-based composts
  • using only organic methods (no synthetic fertilisers or herbicides)
  • cycling nutrients effectively
  • providing excellent habitat for microorganisms
  • providing a diverse food source for birds and invertebrates
  • making use of waste materials

People Care and Fair Share
This design will support the broader project, for which people care and fair share are integral. 

Reflection

My reflection document can be found here. I'm sorry, I was a bit hyper at the prospect of finishing my fifth design. It means I'm nearly kinda halfway through.

I would also say that as I did this documentation retrospectively it meant that I saw the project and the design process from a different perspective. I can now see that the way I presented my design ideas to my employers was far from ideal as I used Miro. Presenting in this format is much better and in future I would try to present a completed design. I'd also make sure that planning and design time was included in any job spec.

My tutor wanted me to write something about why I think the solutions fit the goals well. 

  • make enough compost to meet needs on site to be community sufficient I don't know if this sufficient compost would have been made, but this would have been assessed after a couple of years and the production could have been ramped up! 
  • close the loop of organic material being wasted/processed inefficiently This would certainly have been achieved
  • create low maintenance systems If the designs were followed, using the same materials I'd chosen, then they would have lasted a good long time and remained fairly low maintenance
  • make sure that weeds are composted effectively so that weed seed and roots are killed in the process The compost systems I chose should have dealt with the weeds effectively
  • design durable systems - sustainability is met through implementation of ethics I chose materials that would last as long possible, so I believe that this goal would have been met. 
  • place systems where they are needed I am happy with where I placed each system, but without seeing them in place, I can't say exactly how effective they were. 

One shortcoming of my design was that I didn't include a plan for roles, how people were involved, and how to train people, so with hindsight, I think that this really should have been included, and put in the implementation plan. In the future, I would definitely do this, rather than just saying I would include it in another design. I think that was a bit of a cop out. Tsk tsk.

You made it this far. Thank you very much. You are richly rewarded with a joke;

Q. What is Mozart doing now?

A. Decomposing.

Images are all author's own

 

May all beings be happy and peaceful.

entry.title: 4. Being Well
entry.content:
Overview

Aim

To develop a process that helps me come to terms with my health issues and to heal where I can.

Date

January 2020 - to date

Location

Me

Client

Me

Status

Implemented and ongoing
Submitted for interim portfolio assessment, assessment pending

Area of Application

Health/Spiritual/Wellbeing

Principles

 The Design Principles, from David Holmgren in Permaculture Principles & Pathways Beyond Sustainabilty 

 

Framework

Design Web

By Looby Macnamara

Tools

Client interview, Spirals of erosion/abundance, web of connections, biotime log, zoning, De Bon's Thinking Hats, Rose/Thorn/Bud tool

Resources

'Survival Guide to Staying Conscious’ by Burgs 

'Period Power' by Maisie Hill

'People and Permaculture' by Looby Macnamara

Context

As a means to dealing with various health issues, I decided to create a design that would help me navigate my way through chronic pain, and all consequences of this. I started it in January 2020, when I was suffering from a frozen shoulder. Healing is a slow process. The design has evolved and I have re-worked it where I felt it would help me in my current state of health.

 

This design process was a very personal one. I wouldn't want to put anyone through having to read it, other than the assessors - they're getting paid.

So if you're interested, I've whittled it down into a little presentation that you can watch.

entry.content:

  • Vision

Overview 

 

Aim

My overall objective for completing the diploma is to use it to help me become a functional, useful citizen of the world, to be part of the Give Back Generation

Date

18/06/20 - to date

Location

West Yorkshire, U.K

Client

Myself

Status

ongoing

Submitted for interim portfolio assessment, assessed and amendments completed

Area of Application

Education and Training

Principles

Starhawk’s Common Sense Principles

Framework

Design Web, by Looby Macnamara

Tools

Personal values clarification exercise, Skills Trees, Design Selection tool, River of Life, mind map, matrix form, wall planner, De Bono's Thinking Hats, Rose, Bud, Thorn

Resources/support

People and Permaculture by Looby Macnamara

The Survival Guide to Staying Conscious by Burgs

Action Learning Pathway Guide by the Permaculture Association

Miro, Mindomo, Word, Google Documents, worditout.com

Context

For the Diploma in Applied Permaculture Design, I must complete ten designs. In order to facilitate this process, I have created an Action Learning Pathway, and this is the design for it. It is a map of my learning intentions/aspirations and an exploration into why I am doing the diploma and what I hope to gain from it.

Vision

Allow yourself to dream and create goals

I used this anchor point to think about what I hoped to gain from doing the diploma and also more broadly about how I want to live my life.

The Give Back Generation

I have been resistant to putting this into the world, because it may seem a bit worthy, but it really is at the core of my diploma and my life. Permaculture to me is Buddhist practice put into practice! It's about Earth Care, People Care and Fair share, all ethics that fit within the teachings of the Buddha, but with Permaculture they have practical application. The Give Back Generation is about recognising that you already have enough, and that it's time to give back. My teacher Burgs explains it here.

I wrote a timeline of my life, and then used this to create a 'river of life' drawing'. Sounds a bit hippy to me but it's a real permaculture tradition. I did enjoy seeing the representation of my life on paper. It is too personal to share here, and the past is the past. Suffice to say, like everyone. I've had my ups and downs. It helped me to see the different phases of my life and to see that I am now in a phase where I take responsibility for my own actions and would like to make a conscious effort to shape my life into the best it can be.  'Energy flows where attention goes' and I would like to use my diploma to channel my attention into the things that really matter, to put some really good bends in the river and manage any upcoming rapids so that they don't capsize me. That's enough of that metaphor. 

To get an idea of where I am at now, have a look at my Permaculture CV.

Values

I did an exercise on identifying ones personal values, as part of a Richard Perkins course.
The completed from is here but to summarise, the ten values that scored the highest are shown below;

Aspirations

I have given some thought to how I want to live my life. I hope to;

  • live lightly
  • develop my connection to nature
  • nurture relationships
  • let go of that which doesn't serve me
  • give back
  • be happy
  • nurture creativity

Aims

I would like to finish the diploma with a deep understanding of a wide range of permaculture frameworks, processes, tools and approaches.

I'd like to get to the stage where I can incorporate these into my garden design work, my business, my relationships and all aspects of my life.

I would like to create a portfolio that has a diverse range of applications, such as land stewardship, health and wellbeing, community development etc. However, my main focus will be land stewardship.

Community is often at the heart of permaculture projects. I must say that this is something that I find very challenging but I am always drawn to community projects. I hope to find solutions for this aspect of my work. 

I hope to complete my accreditation in August 2022. 

I would like to create a portfolio of designs that help me with my aspirations as a Buddhist.

Objectives

  • I will create a diverse portfolio of designs
  • All my designs will fit in with my aspirations 
  • I will complete my diploma by August 2022

Helps

Identify the things that are going to help

Internal resources

I did a skills audit, using the Skills tree tool. Unfortunately, I spilt tea on the document so I'm in two minds as to whether or not to put pictures of them on here. But just to give you an idea, they provided me with a visual representation of my skills set. I could see the gaps, and in the future I could use them to identify which of those gaps I would like to fill. 
I scored highest in the following areas:

  • Working precisely with instruments, tools, food
  • 'Green fingers', garden skills
  • Imagining, inventing, creating, designing

Funnily enough, I scored zero on the 'analysing, breaking sown into parts' section. I think I can revisit the skills tree when I've completed my diploma, as then my analytical skills should be much improved!

External resources

  • Office space
  • Diploma Forum – weekly/monthly online meetings for six-week blocks – sign up if stuck
  • Guild – weekly online meetings with a small group of diploma students, sharing designs, check-ins and commitments
  • Regular tutorials and catch ups with tutor Carla
  • Bradford Area Permaculture Women group
  • Diploma Facebook group – I can ask a question for clarification on any point and am pretty much guaranteed an answer.
  • Supportive partner

Networks

Created on mindomo

Inspiration

By biggest inspirations are nature and the teachings of my meditation teacher Burgs.
Specific to permaculture, I gain a lot of inspiration from seeing posts from people on Instagram, I follow a lot of permaculture people and hashtags.

I also love attending permaculture events and hearing about other student's design work via forums, the guild I'm part of and accreditation events. I have a small group of friends who live in my area who are into permaculture and they are all very inspiring. I have tried organising in-person meet-ups but it's like herding cats.

I would like to explore the work of Joanna Macy further.

Limits

What might block the way, slow me down, or keep it small?

  • Looking at other people’s designs and feeling inadequate
  • Getting a job and not having enough time to work on designs
  • Not looking at things objectively when I get stuck
  • Having quite a chaotic thought process that takes me off on tangents

Patterns

Identify helpful and unhelpful patterns
I haven't indicated which of the following patterns are helpful and which are unhelpful, because they can all be either. The best approach for me is to be aware of these habits and utilise them to my own benefit. 

  • I obsess over details Excellent, details are important at times. But when focussing on details becomes a way of procrastinating, a tight deadline prevents me from getting waylaid.
  • I am a perfectionist Excellent, perfection is important at times. But when wanting perfection becomes a way of procrastinating, the phrase 'good enough is good enough' is useful.
  • I am non-linear in my thinking so bounce around with different ideas and go off on tangents Miro is great for this, I can put all my thoughts in an appropriate place.
  • When I am determined and motivated, I can chip away at something and stay focussed Flow is a lovely state to be in, but difficult to get back into once it's broken. I will keep phone on silent and stay off social media when studying. 
  • I work well with short deadlines (I rock the lastminute.com method) and structure Keep the timeline as a guide but work realistically and with self-compassion
  • I am a visual learner Miro! Pinterest! Website! 

In 2018 I completed the RHS Level 3 Diploma in Applied Horticulture with distinction. I also have a BA honours degree. So I know I can study and I know how I study; I leave things to the last moment and then work fixatedly. 

Ideas

Gather inspirations

I had lots of ideas, so I made an epic mindmap. 

I came up with a lot of design ideas

Created on worditout.com

Then life happened and the list changed. 

The list is morphing all the time, but the latest version is as follows;

  1. Action Learning Pathway
  2. Portfolio Presentation 
  3. Kitchen Garden
  4. Being Well
  5. Community Structure
  6. Whole-site fertility design
  7. Food forest
  8. Bird's garden
  9. Jud & Brian support
  10. Benji
  11. Liking where I live
  12. Fairview Court garden
  13. Gardening business design

Yes, that's more than ten. 

I don't want to fix which designs I'm going to do because as I complete the designs, I will start to see where I need to develop my skills and I can choose designs that serve that need.

Principles

Everything is connected

 

All the designs are connected in many ways, some support all of the others, earlier ones support those that follow, as I develop my learning. And as I generally have had more than one design in progress at any time, they influence each other as they progress.
This design is key at making sure that those connections are recognised and exploited.
Nature moves in circles

Learning cycle – organic flow. The more you learn, the more you don’t know!
Energy is abundant but not unlimited

Reuse, recycle. Borrowing from other diploma student's diplomas, getting inspiration from other people’s ALPs
Do more with less

Stacking, make elements serve more than one function – The repurposing of my website is a good way of stacking. I would like an interface to present my designs, I’d like to write about the process, and I’d like to get into writing again, so writing up my designs will get me started.
Use on-site and local resources whenever possible

Use skills I already have, and ask friends/networks to help when stuck.

Don’t buy books, borrow.
If it ain't broke, don't fix it

Make do with what you’ve got. I’m not going to try to do a design for something way off in the future, but design for what’s in front of me instead. Mostly…I would like to do a bit ‘dream set up’ design – i.e moving to Ireland and getting land with a collective.

I will design for now.
Resilience is true security

Diverse sources of help – forum and guild, Facebook diploma group and Permaculture Official UK

Using range of principles, frameworks, tools etc.

Make mistakes, start slow and small and tweak away. I tried using a Gantt chart but it was too complicated, so I used a basic chart. Maybe this will turn out to be too basic but it’s an experiment.

Design for catastrophe – what if I have to get a full-time job and can’t find time to do my designs? How do I design for that? Having an ALP gives me a road map through my diploma, so I will already have assessed the risks, challenges etc.

First things first; doing the ALP before doing any more designs is setting a strong foundation for the rest of my diploma. Yay!
Take responsibility

The cornerstone of the Buddha's teachings, this is what the law of Karma teaches us.  With my ALP I would like to focus on designs that will help me grow, and to bring about positive change. I will try not to ‘make war on what I don’t want’ but rather design for what can be improved
Get some! Obtain a yield! 

I will decide the yield I want and plan for it. My yield will be a cohesive portfolio of designs, new skills and knowledge.

 
Creativity is an unlimited resource Creative thinking is the best way of finding solutions and this design will help me find new ways of being creative, of coming up with new tools, new perspectives and new approaches.

Ethics

People Care is met because I am designing a life for myself that is fulfilling, healthy and compassionate. As my core aim is to be part of the Give Back Generation, care for other people is integral to the design.

Earth Care is met because part of being in the Give Back Generation is to tread lightly, to reduce what I take out. Working with a deep connection with nature is integral to this.

Future Care is met because, as part of the Give Back Generation, I will be taking out less and hopefully having a positive effect on the future of the planet.

Integration

Bring it all together

What are my needs within the design?

Need Solution
Real deadlines Set deadlines and use the buddy system to make sure I stick to them
Organisation Identify apps/software/posters/calendar that will help me
Recording ideas/thoughts Miro for sticky notes
Momentum Regular check-ins and attendance/interaction with various people/groups and networks
Decision process for which design ideas/partly finished designs are developed for final portfolio Create a form for this
Clarity about what areas of application to focus on Assess areas of application and select favourites
Authentic portfolio relevant to my life/aims  Create diagram of how designs relate to my life and one another.

I went through the list of ‘areas of application’ and highlighted the ones that were of most interest to me.

  • Site / land development (although I prefer to call it land stewardship)
  • System development & implementation
  • Architecture, building & retrofitting
  • Personal development, “Zone 00”, health and well-being, etc.
  • Community Development      
  • Education & training
  • Design Consultancy   
  • Finance          
  • Manufacturing
  • Research        
  • Art, Media, Culture & Communication           
  • Administration & organisational design
  • Business
  • Trusteeship
  • Other- general

Action

Make a plan for getting it all done

I created an action timeline and included significant dates and the following (and many more items);

  • Re-work old blog to present the portfolio
  • Use Instagram to document diploma process
  • Set up reminders in Google calendar
  • Weekly check-ins with the FB group
  • Weekly guild meetings
  • Join forum if needed
  • Attend diploma Monthly Online Gatherings hosted by the Permaculture Association
  • Get a buddy 
  • Create a tool that facilitates the decision process for which designs go into final portfolio
  • Use assessment forms and criteria to make sure that I'm on track

The timeline can be seen here
I kept this very flexible. Marking items as complete is great motivation for me.

I have created a Design Selection tool
I have used this for each design I've considered and will include them in the presentation of each design, so that my thinking behind their inclusion can be seen.

I modified the matrix form that was given to me by my tutor. It helps me to keep track of which tools, frameworks, principles etc. I have used, and to see any gaps. This will mean that my learning is diverse. 
It's a great visual tool and I find it satisfying.

Momentum

Consider how to keep going

I drew up a draft of this design, with a timeline, and then duly forgot about it. However, over the months I was working on designs and ticking other boxes, such as using networks etc. I just wasn't following the timeline.

Now that I've left it all rather close to the deadline, I have all the momentum I need. This is just how I work. 

I have reworked the timeline and I now update it regularly.

Appreciation

Focus on things to be thankful for

I am very grateful to my tutor Carla. She's awesome. She has kept me on track, has reminded me to look at criteria etc, pointed me towards other resources/support, and has been an inspiring, balanced and thoughtful guide. She might complain about the length of that sentence. I won't blame her, it's horrendous. 

The guild that I'm, which I like to call the Get Shit Done Club is just lovely. It's made up of people with integrity, humour, compassion and honesty. They have been a huge support to me in this process. We have shared designs, talked through design processes, challenges and ideas.  We've also shared a lot of laughter. I would not have met these fabulous people if I weren't doing the diploma. 

I am very grateful to Killian who when I met him said that permaculture was just 'herb spirals and wafting about with willow'. Now he wants to study it. He has been a great asset as another pair of eyes, providing insightful observations and ideas. And he was crucial to the Portfolio Presentation design

I am hugely grateful to the Permaculture Association for hosting this course. When are they going to set up a degree in Permaculture? That's what I want to know!

That is an extreme misquote, I didn't say that at all.

-Killian

Reflection

Focus area Rose Thorn Bud
Aims/objectives I think that these are quite clear. I am happy with them I struggle to understand what the difference is between goals, aims and objectives. I think that I have managed to use them correctly in this design. As I haven't really addressed the aim about community within the design, this is something I could go back to.
Tools I feel as though I am getting better at knowing which tool to use for a task. Creating my own was really cool and it worked well.  Developing the matrix to suit my needs was helpful and I've shared it with other diploma students who have found it helpful. I do struggle with the concept of a 'river of life' because it seems a bit self-indulgent. However, reflecting on my life was very useful for the design process.  I would like to create a diagram that links all the designs up - showing how they connect.
Framework Having struggled with the Design Web previously, I got to know it better through this design.  I struggled to figure out what design aspects went where. I don't know where survey, analysis, design decisions or implementation go. These are required for assessment. When I use it again, I will follow the books's advice a bit more closely
Ethics I feel that because of my aspirations, the ethics underpin this design strongly I don't like to write too much, so I'm not sure how well I have explained how the ethics affect this design I would like to bring the ethics in nearer to the beginning of the design process next time
Principles I liked Starhawk's principles as they're nice and simple.  I still feel as though they're a bit shoe-horned in. I think that they're in my thinking from the start but not particularly consciously. To bring principles in near the start of future designs
Vision I really like this part of the design web. Hopes and dreams may sound wishy-washy, but if we only think small, we will never get anywhere near reaching our potential I was hesitant to share my vision, but actually, it is so integral to the design that I couldn't leave it out. And although it's personal, I want to share it, because it is powerful. I'd like to include this in every design I do. Dream big and then see what can become of those dreams
Analysis By identifying my needs, I was able to come up with some great solutions. This may seem obvious, but the process made me think things through in a methodical way, highlighting things that I wouldn't have considered.     
Decisions Creating a tool to help me decide which designs/design ideas to include was really helpful.    
Implementation I am putting the tools to good use and they are supporting my learning Keeping the timeline updated is tricky, because life is fluid - things change!  After my IPA I will reassess the implementation
Reflection The Thinking Hats tool is my new favourite tool. It worked really well as a way of seeing my design through different perspectives.  I still find the definition of evaluation and reflection a little unclear, but perhaps that is because I've used the Design Web, and Evaluation isn't an anchor point. I will use a framework that includes both Reflection and Evaluation so that I can get to grips with the differences.
Evaluation I like using the Rose, bud, Thorn tool for this, it keeps it concise. as above as above

Pause

Incorporate time for rest and rejuvenation

My favourite tool for this part is Strictly Come Dancing videos on Youtube. I have a cup of tea and watch until I feel rejuvenated.
Please vote for Rose. 

I have also timetabled in visits to meet up with friends and not talk about permaculture. 

I spend at least an hour outside everyday, and meditate most mornings. So twelve hours at my computer is fine, right? 

Cake is off the menu just now - see the Being Well design...

Evaluate

Evaluate progress

In the process of writing this design, I did quite a bit of waffly evaluation, which I won't subject anyone to. So I'm going to use the De Bono's Thinking Hats tool to summarise.

I'd like to look at each design I've chosen and see how they correlate with my overall objectives.

  • live lightly
  • develop my connection to nature
  • nurture relationships
  • let go of that which doesn't serve me
  • give back
  • be happy
  • nurture creativity

Design 1. Portfolio Presentation
This facilitates the presentation and creation of my permaculture diploma so indirectly, it meets all of my aspirations. It directly meets my aspiration to nurture creativity and to give back. And it did make me very happy!

Design 2. Kitchen Garden 
My aspiration to develop my connection with nature is met by this design. The process nurtured my creativity and had it been implemented, would have helped me meet the others. Funnily enough, the process did help me 'let go of that which doesn't serve me', because I realised that the project wasn't for me and I needed to walk away from it.

Design 3. Action Learning Pathway
As per my first design, this one supports all of my aspirations, rather than meeting them directly. The aspiration to nurture creativity was met directly though.

Design 4. Being Well
'Letting go of that which doesn't serve me' was the main focus of this design. developing my connection to nature was an important factor too and my other aspirations were supported by it indirectly.

Design 5. Compost
The key aspiration for this design was to 'give back'. Giving back to the soil, regenerating soil life and soil structure - this is very important to me and it's important to remember that giving back isn't just about helping humans.

Although none of the designs will directly meet all of my aspirations, they should all meet at least one of them, support them all indirectly and definitely not hinder them in any way.

Tweak

I have just hit an impasse with my next design, and I realised that I don't have anything in my ALP about what to do if this happens. I would like to make a flowchart so that I have a process for this situation, to avoid having a big delay and getting behind schedule.

I will return to this design throughout the process of creating my final five designs, so there may well be a ALP part two!

Here's a picture of one of my heroes, Miriam Margolyes. Because why the heck not.

May all beings be happy and peaceful.

entry.title: 2. Kitchen Garden Design
entry.content:
Table of Contents

  • Overview
  • Goal articulation
  • Survey
    • Site systems and elements
  • Analysis
    • Limiting factors
    • Resources
    • Accessibility
    • Soil improvement systems
    • Permaculture Ethics
  • Decision Making
    • Kitchen garden placement
    • Raised bed layout
    • Soil Improvement systems placement
    • Other decisions
    • The final design
  • Implementation
  • Manage
  • Evaluate
  • Permaculture Principles
  • Reflection on the design process

 

Overview

Aim

To create a functional, accessible kitchen garden that will allow people of all abilities, physicalities and ages to enjoy growing edible plants.

Date

23.06.21 - 18.08.21

Location

 West Yorkshire, U.K.

Client

 Private

Status

Not implemented
Submitted for interim portfolio assessment, assessment complete, amendments complete

Domain

 Land/Nature stewardship

Principles

The Design Principles, from David Holmgren in Permaculture Principles & Pathways Beyond Sustainabilty 

Framework

GoSADIM

Goal setting, Survey, Analysis, Decision Making, Implementation, Manage
Then the additional steps of Evaluate & Tweak

By Graham Burnett at Spiral Seed  

Tools

Functions/Systems/Elements chart, PASTE, DAFOR, sector analysis, overlays, mindmap, Strengths/Weaknesses/Needs/Challenges chart, flowchart, Gantt chart, Roses, Buds & Thorns.

Resources/support

Visit to Ashton Walled Community Garden in Preston, Miro, Suncalc.org, Pinterest, Google Earth

Context

This design is about creating a functional and accessible kitchen garden to be used by a community for learning, connecting with nature, socialising and having fun

The client wanted to install a kitchen garden that would be the focus for activities for community groups. There is no kitchen for the garden to serve at present. 

This was the extent of the brief.  The client left it to me to create a garden that could be part of a sustainable business and part of a bigger project that utilised the gardens on the larger site. 

I decided to use this opportunity to create my dream kitchen garden, and one that would be accessible to as many people as possible. I decided to use materials that had the least ecological impact and to include elements that would benefit all aspects of the environment, where possible.

Local consultation was not possible, but I would hope that this would take place at some point, within the design of the larger project. 

Goal articulation

What I want.

I would like to create a garden that;

  • produces a wide variety of fruit and vegetables
  • increases biodiversity
  • provides opportunities for people to learn about and connect with nature/the growing process
  • is accessible for everyone and can engage a diverse range of people
  • is not only sustainable but also regenerative
  • strengthens the local community and is shaped by the local community
  • looks beautiful, to inspire and engage
  • uses environmentally friendly and organic methods - reducing waste, recycling/reusing. free from pesticides, herbicides, no peat, no dig, less fossil fuels (hand tools rather than power tools)
  • uses local resources, especially waste from on site, e.g. woodchip, leaves and grass clippings

I created a mood board on Pinterest.

Survey

What I've got.

#Observe and interact

The survey was not as in-depth as I would have liked, due to the following factors;  I had a very short deadline for completing this design, accessing the site was problematic and the number of people on site to ask for more information was very limited.

You can see all my survey information on this Miro board, but Miro isn't for everyone, so I have included almost everything else below.

I took some photos of the site and mapped them here to indicate viewpoint.
The screenshot below gives you an idea, but by clicking on the link above you will be able to zoom in to get a better look.

A selection of the photos are below:

I used a variety of maps to indicate the geographical location

Site systems and elements

To identify what was already on the site I did the following;

I created a base map using Google Earth;

The area selected for the kitchen garden can be seen below, marked in turquoise. The raised bed area is marked in pink. The measurements needed for calculating the raised bed area are shown in yellow

I used the PASTE acronym to help me categorise what was within the walled garden. I only listed plants within the kitchen garden area. 

I then used the DAFOR acronym to indicate the frequency of each plant

You can read my site assessment here

Due to time constraints, I have only done a very basic sector analysis. I have not made observations myself, but have used general data available on the internet. This is sufficient for the project. 

Shade will not affect the design per se, but will influence how crops are grown, but that is not within the remit of this design. 

The greenhouse to the east of the raised bed area will cast some shade at times.

The Horse Chestnut to the south of the raised bed area will also cast some shade at times.

The trees to the west, north and east of the site will provide a windbreak, as will the walls that surround the whole site. Again, this is only really relevant to the growing of crops.

The site is fairly exposed, especially as a large number of very tall conifers have recently been cut down. These used to surround the kitchen garden site. Further developments of the site, such as the creation of a forest garden, may well provide protection. 

The site is on private land with security gates and at present there is no access to the public. This may change, depending on what happens to the site.

The hall is a Grade II listed building. The walls of the walled garden are included in this. They have fallen into disrepair but will be refurbished in 2022

Analysis

What the limiting factors and potential resources are.

Through analysis, our challenge is to design and establish a system where the energy needed to maintain it decreases over time, while its outputs increase  - Aranya, Permaculture Design

Limiting factors


Physical limiting factors
There is no water catchment at present.
The irrigation system is limited to one tap, which is by the wall to the east. This is a long way from where the kitchen garden has been sited.
Deer have access to the site via the car park entrance.
Squirrels, rabbits and pigeons are likely to damage crops
There are several areas that may be problematic for accessibility for those using wheelchairs/other mobility aids - different levels, trip hazards, broken paths etc.

Non - physical limiting factors
There are many unknowns - funding, community engagement logistics, local residents' reactions, communication systems.
There has been no consultation with the local community. 
There are many separate parties involved. We do not know each other very well, and the communication system is long-winded. Communication is disjointed, objectives are unclear etc.
We do not own the land.
We do not know if the design will be implemented.
At present, we do not have a tenure agreement.
No local people have been involved in this project as yet.

Resources

Woodchip and leaves from the site
Greenhouse
We may have workers from CC, in the form of young people on a training programme
ST infrastructure - accounts, email system, established business w contacts etc.
Knowledge and skills - myself and Killian have excellent skills in  growing, organisation, teaching and planning
ST will be part of the implementation and organisation/admin
It has now become clear that the land owners have a budget for this project, and they want us to submit a proposal so that they can see how much money is required.

I created this mind map to help me think about all the different elements that could be involved. Click on the mindmap to go to Miro, where you can zoom in. 

I looked at my Goal Articulation and identified the functions;

  • produces a wide variety of fruit and vegetables Food production
  • increases biodiversity Biodiversity
  • provides opportunities for people can come to learn and connect with nature/the growing process Education
  • is accessible for everyone and can engage a diverse range of people Accessibility
  • is not only sustainable but also regenerative Biodiversity
  • strengthens the local community and is shaped by the local community Community Integration
  • looks beautiful, to inspire and engage Aesthetic
  • uses environmentally friendly and organic methods - reducing waste, recycling/reusing. free from pesticides, herbicides, no peat, no dig, less fossil fuels (hand tools rather than power tools) this will be achieved via the ethic of Earth Care
  • uses local resources, especially waste from on site, e.g woodchip, leaves - this will be achieved through connecting systems

I then created a Function, Systems, Elements chart to help me see how the different elements serve the different functions. It is said that a truly resilient design would only include systems and elements that serve at least three functions. Some of the elements and systems only appear once or twice on the chart, so perhaps it isn't a resilient design. 

Accessibility

I wanted to know how we could make the site highly accessible. I collated the information and created a document using information that I found on the Thrive website. #useandvaluediversity

There were a number of different options when it came to choosing materials for the paths around the raised beds. I used a 'Strengths. Weaknesses, Needs and Challenges' chart to help me make a comparison. You can also see it here

Soil improvement systems

The larger site provides organic waste that could be recycled within the kitchen garden. Trees are cut down on occasion, the lawns are mown frequently and leaves are gathered from the lawns. Employees from the main buildings may provide food waste that could be processed. #catchandstoreenergy

I looked at different composting systems; then identified waste products from on the site or locally that could be utilised. #producenowaste

I created a flowchart to see how different waste products from the site could be distributed.

Permaculture Ethics

Earth Care Biodiversity will be increased through the use of a diverse number of systems and elements
  I have opted for recycled plastic planks for the raised bed as they are the most eco-friendly option
   
People Care Accessibility is a key function. education
   
Fair Share Any produce will initially go to any volunteers and if there is surplus, it can be donated to those in need. 

Decision Making

What I need to change.

Kitchen garden placement

The decision of where to place the kitchen garden was straightforward. The area next to the greenhouse previously had raised beds, so some paths are already in place. Also, it is close to the greenhouse. Putting it anywhere else would have been far more complicated and resource heavy. #smallandslowsolutions #patternstodetails

There had been some discussion about developing the whole walled garden site. I came up with a rough idea of what could be done and this can be seen below;

There is the potential to expand the kitchen garden further, at a later date

Raised bed layout

I had to decide on the layout of the raised beds, using the dimensions defined by my accessibility research. I tried a few different configurations that can be seen here

The layout that I chose is made up of a pattern of seven beds that is repeated twice. If funding doesn't allow, just one set could be built. 

With two sets, there were two areas left to fill where plants could be grown. I decided a herb garden would be a simple element in one of the areas. Herbs will provide a crop and also food and habitat for wildlife, including pollinators. #Obtain a yield I decided to plant green manures in the other area to suppress weeds and enrich the soil. This could be developed later to grow other plants, perhaps more herbs. 

Soil Improvement systems placement

Having looked a the options I decided that all of the systems would work well on the site, as they all utilised waste that was readily available, and I anticipated that we would need a lot of compost. 

The siting for the systems changed, but the original placement can be seen here.

When I came to drawing up the design, I realised that there was a better place for the composting systems, near the greenhouse door where a path already exists - this would make the composting system accessible straight away. #integrateratherthansegregate

Other decisions

I decided to use hazel obelisks and arches to make use of the vertical, for growing crops such as peas, sweet peas, etc.  

I chose two areas for bug hotels. #obtainayield 

I placed the seating area by the greenhouse on an area that is fairly flat and will have a nice view of the raised beds.

The gutters of the greenhouse are quite low down, so small water butts will be installed to collect water.

The tap shown on the basemap is the only source of irrigation, so a hose system will be set up from this.

The final design

Implementation

How I will achieve the change.

The costings of the raised beds are shown below:

 

I started workplan using a Gantt chart, Because I didn't know if the project was going to go ahead, I decided not to proceed with it. If the project is approved I will continue with the planning.

Manage

How I will continue to manage and maintain this project.

The project is now on hold. 

Evaluate

were your project aims met through the design solution you created? Was the design solution effective?

My overall aim was to create a functional, accessible kitchen garden that will allow people of all abilities, physicalities and ages to enjoy growing edible plants.

The design solution will achieve this very nicely, although just how well it does so will only be known in time, should it be implemented as per my design. 

In my goal articulation, I spoke broadly about what I would like to achieve, but again, many of those goals will not be fulfilled until the design has been implemented. There is no reason to think that they would not all be met.

  • produces a wide variety of food crops The beds provide enough space to grow a good variety of crops
  • increases biodiversity Although to create the beds a good number of volunteer plants will need to be removed, the overall project will make up for this loss and the introduction of a wide variety of other plants will increase the biodiversity.
  • provides opportunities for people to learn and connect with nature/the growing process The learning opportunities provided by the kitchen garden are excellent.
  • is accessible for everyone and can engage a diverse range of people The site should be highly accessible as I carefully followed the guidelines given by Thrive 
  • is not only sustainable but also regenerative Although this is a little vague, the kitchen garden can regenerate the land by increasing biodiversity and having people on the site to care for it, drawing people in to get involved with other regenerative projects
  • strengthens the local community and is shaped by the local community Having provided the design, local people could be invited to develop the project and take ownership of it
  • looks beautiful, to inspire and engage This is subjective, but to my mind the design is aesthetically pleasing and would inspire and engage others
  • uses environmentally friendly and organic methods - reducing waste, recycling/reusing. free from pesticides, herbicides, no peat, no dig, less fossil fuels (hand tools rather than power tools) I recommended and costed for recycled plastic materials for the raised beds but I have no control over if any of these or any of the environmentally methods are used.
  • uses local resources, especially waste from on site, e.g. woodchip, leaves and grass clippings Apart from the woodchipped area, I did not incorporate these resources into this design. An additional compost design could include them in the future. 

 

 

Permaculture Principles

Here I look at the principles a bit more in-depth than just sticking a hashtag next to them! 

Observe and interact Through doing a survey I learnt a lot about the site and noted some issues that needed addressing. This helped me create a realistic budget and will help to calculate how long tasks will take to complete, should I get to the stage of completing the work plan.
Catch and store energy The composting systems do this nicely. 
Obtain a yield The garden will provide opportunities for learning and connection with natural processes, whilst also providing food and habitat for wildlife
Apply self-regulation and accept feedback

Although creating a kitchen garden where the focus isn't about growing crops may seem strange, it is actually appropriate to the mother project. If the mother project goes ahead, the kitchen garden will provide many benefits. If the mother project doesn't go ahead, the kitchen garden can still function as a discrete system.

Taking on the role of stewardship of this land means that I have a responsibility to the wildlife community as well as human community, so I have included as many regenerative solutions as possible, such composting systems, water catchment, permeable paths and raised beds made of sustainable materials.
Use and value renewable resources and services

By making as much compost on site as possible, the need for buying in from elsewhere is reduced. 

By using a water catchment system, the need for using mains water is reduced
Produce no waste A diverse range of composting systems means that all the organic waste from the larger site can be utilised efficiently and create something of high value
Design from patterns to details Placing the kitchen garden where raised gardens had been previously meant that the systems already in place, such as paths and the greenhouse, would support the new garden.
Integrate rather than segregate Re-thinking the placement of the three bay compost system meant that paths that were already there would provide greater accessibility
Use small and slow solutions Make the least change for the greatest effect - by placing elements where existing infrastructure existed meant that energy and other resources could be used elsewhere. 
Use and value diversity By making the site accessible to all, a diverse range of people will be able to come and interact with the garden. Diversity is at the heart of this project, that aims to be of benefit to as many people and creatures as possible.
Use edges and value the marginal A constraint of this design is that it cannot yet show how this garden will fit in with the other elements of the bigger project. There will be a good deal of edge. 
Creatively use and respond to change The pandemic has meant that more people want to be outside, there is an increased demand for outdoor activities, and hopefully these needs can be met in part by this project. 

Reflection on the design process

What I learnt about permaculture through the design process
I learnt a new framework.

I am starting to see that there is skill in selecting what to survey and to what level of detail to record data.

I feel as though I'm getting the hang of what is a function, a system and an element - this really baked my noodle but by going through it methodically, it started to make sense.

Through having not done a sector analysis, I started to see it's purpose!

What I learnt about myself through the design process
I recognise that I wasn't methodical enough. I realised that in rushing ahead with ideas meant that I missed important steps out, steps that would have facilitated deeper thought processes. I went back over things where I could, but it was too late to make changes to the final design. To be fair to myself, the deadline was a tight one and I didn't really have time for much deliberation. Once I have completed the diploma, those processes should be well imbedded into my thought processes so that I use them automatically.

How this design process has helped me
It has helped me to see the process I would follow with sufficient time. Looking back at it now, it has made me think of other opportunities that are on the site, such as water catchment on a big scale, and incorporating rain gardens.

What went well?
I realised that I should have done a client interview. As it would have been like shutting the gate after the horse had bolted, I looked at the goal articulation and defined the functions from this. It was a bit of a bodge job, but it worked just fine. I was pleased that I had come up with a solution...a solution for a problem when looking for a solution for a solution...oh dear, I feel like I'm in the Matrix.

What was challenging?
I thought that using a different framework, one that looked a bit simpler, would make the process easier. This wasn't the case. I think that my main difficulty is working out which elements go under which headings, and that is just something that will become clearer as I progress through the diploma. 

There wasn't enough time for prolonged observation

Long term vision and goals

The long term vision is that this kitchen garden is part of a bigger community garden that is able to sustain itself financially.

Next achievable steps

This project is now on hold, so there are no next achievable steps.

 

ROSE - Signifies a success. What is working well related to the focus area?

THORN - Signifies a challenge. What's not working well related to the focus area?

BUD - Signifies potential. What could be developed related to the focus area?

Focus area Rose Thorn Bud
Goals These helped me picture what it was that I was going for, it really does sound like a wonderful project! These were a bit vague In future designs I could have objectives or smart goals that are measurable
Tools The Functions/Systems/Elements tool helped me see gaps in my thinking My biggest mistake in this project was failing to see who the client was. You might wonder how I could have got this wrong, but the start of this project was  disjointed and confusing, and time was short. Had I pinpointed the true client, I would have done a client interview on them, rather than myself It would have been good to do a diagram to show how the systems intertwined. Sector analysis would have shown how the larger site and buildings would have interacted with the site.
Framework I found it a fairly straightforward framework, I like that goals are considered first  I chose this framework because it seemed fairly straightforward, and it was, except that it offers Evaluation and Tweak as options, but for the accreditation, these need to be included, so I had to go back and do them. I think for my next land-based design I would use SADIMET and follow Aranya's instructions to the letter, so that I know what goes where
Ethics The people care ethic is very strong in this design, as accessibility was a priority. Education was listed as a function, but then not really addressed. I think this comes back to a lack of clarity around the aims of the project. Fair share wasn't addressed sufficiently, although I considered it at length. 
Principles I like the Holmgren principles, they are fairly straightforward I found it difficult to integrate the principles into my write up I feel a bit as though I shoe-horned them in at the end. I will consider them earlier in future
Survey I feel as though the survey is adequate for the design. Good enough is good enough. I would have liked to have had more time to make observations and record data. I would have liked to have measured the height of the surrounding trees. I would have liked to have drawn shade diagrams. Time was not on my side.  I received feedback that a video of the site would have been useful. I will include that in my next land-based design
Analysis Aspects of the design mean that the energy needed to maintain it decreases over time, while its outputs increase I don't feel as though I clearly explained how some of the limiting factors were addressed by the design A more methodical approach would allow for clearer analysis
Decisions I produced a well thought out design, with good accessibility and a pleasing aesthetic.  As this was a fairly straightforward kitchen garden design, I don't feel as though there were any particularly innovative design decisions made.  I didn't include any information about the plant choices. I would do this for the next land based design
Implementation n/a n/a n/a
Evaluation Breaking each section down and using the Rose/Thorn/Bud tool has helped me see the gaps in my work.  This feels much the same as reflection. I'm not sure I have done this part correctly! I will use this process again, either for reflection or evaluation or both, once I have had feedback.

Does this design really lack resilience? If it's the case that a truly resilient design has systems and elements that serve more than one function, this isn't a resilient design. But also, I think that there may be functions that have not been identified or included, so some of the systems and elements are actually doing more than I am giving them credit for. How can it be that everything has to serve three functions? Does this mean that some elements should be excluded?  I would like to explore this in my future design work.

 

May all beings be happy and peaceful.

entry.title: Glossary
entry.content:
Permaculture Principles

Permaculture is a creative design process based on whole-systems thinking informed by ethics and design principles

- David Holmgren

The following principles were written by David Holmgren;

Observe and interact
Catch and store energy
Obtain a yield
Apply self-regulation & accept feedback
Use & value renewable resources & services
Produce no waste
Design from patterns to details
Integrate rather than segregate
Use small and slow solutions
Use and value diversity
Use edges & value the marginal
Creatively use and respond to change

entry.title: Reflection Document
entry.content:
This is the place where I take an overview of my design work and summarise my thoughts on the process. I will identify and discuss the key things that I've learnt, looking at how the designs influenced my learning and each other. I'll go through the most significant realisations I had about the various tools, frameworks and resources that I used.

Midpoint reflection

Although officially I started in 2018, that year was completely taken up with the studentship I did with the RHS. Having said that, I didn’t really start work on it properly until 2020, when I joined the guild. The job at Wibsey (where I did the compost design) also spurred me on - the real need for practical solutions was a boon to my motivation.

I did lots of designs, or at least the bare bones of several designs that didn’t make it into the portfolio. They were an important part of my learning process. I did one about right livelihood, another about the structure of a large-scale community garden project, a cut flower garden design, two forest gardens and a design for the raised beds area at Wibsey, amongst others. But then when I came to document them, I realised that a lot of them had too many big gaps in, so they didn’t make the grade. This informed the first of my key learnings:

The importance of being methodical
I found that following the framework as closely as possible was helpful, although I did find that moving from one step to another that was out of sequence was necessary at times. This was especially true of times when I was struggling with the sequence and really needed to get the clarity that another step could provide, such as having goals/aims. This also helped when I was confused about just what goes under which heading, i.e. analysis.

Tools are really awesome
But you have to find the right one, and if you can’t find the right one, create a new one that fits the job.

As a gardener, I know when to use a fork and not a spade. When a saw is better than loppers. But with Permaculture design, sometimes the right tool isn’t completely obvious. I didn’t always know exactly what I was trying to do. So I modified tools. I started using SWOC, and changed it to SW. I used random assembly but modified it so that it also included notes and ideas that related to specific areas.

As someone who can tend to be a bit too self-critical, I found the reflection tools ‘Roses, Thorns and Buds’ and ‘De Bono’s Six Hats’ were very helpful. They forced my brain to use pathways that it’s not accustomed to, to consider things from different perspectives. How marvellous.

They’re not You
Ok, full disclosure; I’m not actually there yet with this one, but it’s wafting around in my psyche, so I think it’ll manifest at some point…So this is about designing with fixed ideas about how the design should be done, what the client needs and what they should get. The inspiration for this thinking came from a Brenna Quinlan Instagram post and as I read it, I started to hear a little voice (not literally) and a finger gently prodding me (that turned out to be my dog kicking me in his sleep), saying ‘you do that, that’s you that is’. Fair enough, hands up, I am stubborn and a bit too rigid in my thinking. So I’m off to TK Maxx to get myself a whole rainbow of hats. I’ll show that Bono character – six? Better make that ten! HA!

Good enough is good enough
Not usually something I’m particularly good at upholding, but when surveying I think it’s an important one. A lot of time and energy can be saved by really thinking through what is needed. And this is another reason why I think goal setting first is important because otherwise, you might overlook the need to survey some things and survey aspects that you didn’t need to. Going back to do things that you’ve missed off isn’t always possible.

Presentation is Key
Through the documentation process I realised that the way I presented some of my designs to people had a detrimental effect on the projects themselves. My fixation with Miro meant that I didn’t realise that not everyone loved it as much as me. Submitting designs that are only half done is also not helpful as people can’t see how the whole thing fits together. However, when time is short or you’re submitting speculative designs, or not getting paid, it’s hard to give get the balance right. I guess that’s something that comes with experience.

Meta confusion
Ok, so this bakes my noodle massively and it’s going ot be difficult to put into words, so please bear with me.
When I’m working on a design, I can start mixing up the actual design work with the design process. And when evaluating or reflecting (and don’t get me started on how the heck to tell those to heckin’ things apart) I can slide into thinking about the process rather than the design and not realise. It’s something that I struggle with but will probably click into place at some point. I hope.

Other thoughts
I wanted to use my diploma to find practical and/or holistic ways to find positive solutions and I feel as though I’ve done this to certain degree. Because they were done retrospectively, I feel as though sometimes they were a bit gappy. Not having implemented the two land designs meant that a lot of learning was missing and I feel that this is evident from the work presented. I would very much like to fill that gap in the final half of my diploma.

Last thought
Having completed my first five designs I am feeling much more confident in my understanding of permaculture design. So much so that I am finding it hard not to get stuck into the next five right away. I'm supposed to be having a breather though so they'll have to wait. Right?
